text: you might think it's just red and blue
conservatives and liberals that define
American politics but in reality the
political landscape is a bit more
complicated according to new data from
the Pew Research Center you see they've
broken the public into eight types 36%
of Americans fall into three of those
types and they're the most partisan but
a majority of Americans are somewhere in
the middle and they're made up of four
types the young Outsiders these tend to
lean Republican in terms of limited
government but they have liberal views
on social issues and the environment the
hard-pressed skeptics these people got
hit hard by the tough economy and don't
really trust government but they approve
when the government aids the needy the
next generation left young liberal and
pretty affluent these Americans support
all sorts of liberal social platforms
but they worry government social
programs might cost a bit too much and
finally the faith and family Left they
lean pretty democratic on the
government's roll the religiously and
ethnically diverse but not so keen on
progressive changes like same-sex
marriage
what unifies these four types is being
frustrated with politics so that'll be
the tricky part for political candidates
can they find a way to appeal to such a
diverse majority one type they won't
have to worry about are the bystanders
who make up 10% of Americans these
people don't really pay attention to
politics or vote so maybe that means
bystanders just rest easy when it comes
to all of this well as they say
ignorance is bliss
David Botti BBC News Washington
